fields.headline: Steps back in time
fields.bodyText: Recently I climbed a fell on the fringe of Lakeland in the hope of seeing Tibetan prayer flags said to be fluttering near the summit. Too late, they had gone. But the top of Dent, several hundred feet above the streets of Cleator Moor, still had heartening views from Black Combe - via the Isle of Man - to the Galloway coast. Below, the pit wheel of the Florence Mine Heritage Centre at Egremont was a reminder of industrial days gone by. Not for nothing was the "Moor" known as Little Ireland, because of its preponderance of Irish people, who came for work in the iron-ore mining days. LS Lowry, recognising the character of the place, painted here. Having descended between sombre, dark conifers and electrifyingly green larch trees to the road, the question was, where next? St Bees Head, proved the answer: the start (or finish) of the Coast to Coast Walk and alive with kittiwakes, gulls, fulmars, razorbills, guillemots and puffins. Late-afternoon sunshine reflected from the red sandstone cliffs as I descended a steep path. The words of the Petra poem sprang to mind - "a rose-red city, half as old as time". From a pavement as luscious-looking as a slab of Turkish Delight, anglers were casting their lines into a choppy sea: Whitehaven "marras" (a coal-mining term meaning pitface mates). One, shouldering his rods, offered to show me the Smuggler's Steps. This involved pulling up on chains over an increasingly terrifying void and clambering up steps hewn in the cliff. As we topped out, I turned to take one last look at the inky silhouette of Snaefell across the Irish Sea. There on top of the way we had just come was a sign. It read: "Dangerous Cliffs".
